On releasing this video, they hoped to get about 100k views before launching the app but we're lucky enough to have millions of people engaged in their new vision for 'putting email in its place'.

After the launch, they sustained buzz around the product by using a waiting list within the application. A new user would sign up and see their place in the queue, but more importantly, how many people were behind them. This is remarkability at it's core. Everyone was talking about Mailbox in their social circles by comparing their place in the activation queue.

Tile

Back in July I interviewed Mike and Nick from Tile. At that point they were in the middle of their self starter crowdfunding campaign. They were only a couple of hundred thousand dollars in, and already 20x more successful than they expected. By the end of the campaign, they raised $2.6M in crowdfunding presages for their new product. During the interview, I asked the guys what they thought the critical keys to their success were. Apart from answering every question on every blog where people were commenting about the press coverage of Tile, the guys were very focused on what they stood for and what change they were making in the world.

No Android support, no replaceable batteries, one color.

Mike and Nick were not trying to please everyone who had an opinion. They knew that their product would change the lives of their customers and nothing else matters for now. The fact that an Android user slags them off because they don't support his phone, simply didn't both them.

What did you learn about marketing and telling stories from Seth Godin’s Startup School?

posts.title: You Will Fail
posts.markdown:
...but that's okay. Isn't it?

*Over the past month I have had the pleasure of hearing many product and idea pitches. This blog post is long overdue and I have mixed feelings about which way to write. So I'm I'm doing both in two parts.*

## PT 1: AVOIDING FAILURE IS COSTLY

Since when was it not okay to fail? Ok, I know the answer to this question, but now it's your turn. Can you remember when you decided that failure was associated with the end of the world, or your life as you know it? There is a good chance that there is some silly psychology going on and I honestly don't want to explore it. Here's the truth:

**Whatever you create for the first time, will fail.**

Oh you heard a story about someone who had an idea, raised some money, became successful and now they are retired at 25? Nice one. They were lucky - someone had to be. Right?

You won't hear the stories about the person who showed up and did the emotional labor of asking strangers what they thought of their idea, until they worked out who was their market and what story resonated with the way they saw the world. You don't hear this story because it's boring to everyday dreamers who are sold on big dreams, scams and not a lot of hard work. Real entrepreneurs don't value these stories, they don't comment on them. They simply smile and get back to work on things that matter.

Real entrepreneurs know as a sure certainty that whatever they create - the product, the experience, the pitch, the website, the video, the interaction.....will ultimately not fit everyone who intersects with it. **That's okay with them.** It is okay to fail, just do it quick and spend more time on people who are willing to cross the street to see you.

If you accept that whatever you create will not work the way you expected it to, for the people you thought would love it the most, you'll now have two realizations: 

1. Don't waste your life savings, months of your time and burn every network connection you have to get your first prototype into the market.

2. Work out the quickest way to fail and do it **fast.**

## What is failure anyway?

1. You make assumptions.
2. They are wrong.

**Not:** you are a failure as a person, as a provider for your family, as an entrepreneur, as a person with great ideas. No, you simply made assumptions that were wrong.

We all make assumptions about other people that are wrong, but we don't nearly beat ourselves up as much about it (as perhaps we should). Don't be so hard on yourself, you don't know everything...and that's a good thing. 

## How to fail fast

1. Work on just enough of an idea that you can pitch the product to (who you think) is a potential buyer. This must be under 1 minute. Try limit your materials unless you really need mockups. Visuals can aide understanding but also just give you a way to hide. **Don't hide.**

2. Ask great questions. Every pitch I have heard recently involved **me**  asking questions (see Pt 2 below). You are doing the validation, **you** ask the questions.

3. Revise your pitch and do it again until you find the right product/customer fit. You may need to change some of the details in how the product works or how you price it. Or you may need to re-pitch the same product to a new potential customer in a new market. You'll only work this out if you ask great questions. 

4. Ask for the money. If they like your idea and are willing to pay for it, ask for the whole amount or a deposit of $10, or $20 etc. If someone won't give you the money, they are simply being nice and don't really think it's a good idea. Think this is silly? How does Kickstarter work?

There are so many ways you can transfer money instantly. You could take someone to your Kickstarter page or your self-starter page hosted on Wordpress. You could ask them to send money through Paypal or many banking apps now allow you to send money on the fly. 

Why won't you ask for money? You're scared. *(Read on)* 

## PT 2: ARROGANCE WILL COST YOU MORE

It happens to all of us, we all do it. We fall in love with our product concept and the idea of who we think we will be when our venture is successful. This type of thinking will encourage you to stop yourself from failing and cost you much more time and money than ever expected. This is arrogance.

Arrogance is when you: 

* Don't understand who you're pitching to.
* Don't listen to feedback.
* Defend your idea instead of clarifying your understanding and improving your pitch.
* Think that the product is more important than the problem it is solving.
* Mess with probabilities to make your idea sound good (to you). 
* Have no idea about what assumptions you're making. 
* Pick technology first, a product design second and then a customer problem last. 
* Get scared about pitching an idea because someone will steal it.
* Hide behind legals, business structures, equity agreements, insurances, setting up technology, writing policies and procedures....all because you don't want to pitch your product and get rejected.

If you're still reading this and haven't closed the page, you probably have what it takes to get something off the ground. Those people who closed the page may become successful through manipulation of people and finding information gaps in markets, but they'll never know what it's like to delight customers with an exceptional experience and ship a remarkable product.

My hope is that you will change the world, for some people. You will get rid of bad ideas fast and work on things that matter. Like many entrepreneurs, I have made every mistake bulleted above. As you strip the arrogance away you find someone who is scared of what the world will think of them.

Ironically, stripping away your arrogance turns you into a remarkable entrepreneur. Be that person, the world wants you to be.

*Your turn: What are some of your biggest lessons learnt?*

posts.title: How to make your community a trust filter
posts.markdown:
If you and I were in the same (native) tribe, I'd probably listen to, and trust your ideas. I'd also share my food with you and let you look after my family. But if you looked different to me or spoke a different language, I wouldn't trust you.

*Fast forward several thousand years and nothing has (really) changed.* 

However tribes are no longer bounded by geography. They are bounded by trust. Recently, Chris Guillebeau asked his tribe to [help someone for free.](http://chrisguillebeau.com/3x5/help-someone-for-free/) I saw this as an opportunity to connect with some of the AONC community members as they were standing with open arms. A month later, I'm still in contact with [Bree](http://www.breebrouwer.com/), [Jeanne](http://jeanneatkin.com/), and[James](http://www.rinkpodcast.com/). What was different about me contacting them instead of a random stranger? **Trust.**

Chris, along with other influential leaders of tribes (such as [Pat Flynn](http://patflynn.me/) ) inspire trust within a group of people. This act is remarkable. When a community of strangers show up to read/listen to a single person and interact with the community, they aren't doing it for the leader - **they're doing it for themselves.** 

Humans have always wanted to feel connected to each other. However we get lost (and hurt) when there are endless possibilities to connect but no filters of trust.

## BUILD YOUR OWN TRUST FILTER

If you are a remarkable leader, you will have a filter. [Being remarkable means people will not like what you stand for and the things you say.](https://beingremarkable.squarespace.com/blog/what-is-remarkable) **This is good news.**

When you filter out the *wrong* people  (wrong as in 'not right for your tribe'), the *right* people feel safe to connect, tell stories and help each other out. They will trust each other because you have created a filter for the types of people they shouldn't trust.

### How to build your own trust filter

1. Stick to the [edges](http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2006/02/edges_and_clust.html), please some people and not everyone.
2. Encourage your tribe to help others first, and then you. 
3. Don't be afraid of smaller.  [Calling people out who broke the rules](http://chrisguillebeau.com/3x5/help-for-free-results/) may make your tribe a little smaller, but it makes it **much**  stronger.

**What sort of people should join your community?**

*P.S. This is your chance to pitch your community and provide a link to your site/blog. Yes, this is for you...not me.*

posts.title: Three choices of being remarkable
posts.markdown:
Every day you could do something that surprises others. Perhaps you save a puppy from a building on fire or you score a hole-in-one at golf. You might even speak up in a meeting where everyone thought that it was best to stay quite. Yes, these are surprising but are they remarkable? No, I don't believe so.

Think back to a time when you were **brilliant**.

* That time when you felt total success in the project you were working on.
* When you scored the highest.
* When you negotiated your biggest deal.
* When you deeply connected with someone who matters to you.
* When you gave that presentation that had everyone on the edge of their seats.
* When you raised 10x more money that you anticipated for your crowdfunding campaign.

For some, these are random acts where they had good fortune. Perhaps they got picked by someone famous or luck was on their side. Well, someone had to get lucky.

But for most of us, being remarkable is a habit, not an event.

## THREE CHOICES OF BEING REMARKABLE

The habits we choose come in three flavours. We have the habit of deciding, the habit of choosing a destination and the habits that take us on the journey. As Seth wrote[ a few days ago](http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2013/06/angry-is-a-habit.html): 

> Habits are great when they help us get what we want. Bad habits, on the other hand, are bad because the shortcut that satisfies us in the moment gets in the way of our long term goals.

## The Decision

The decision is not an event.

You don't decide once. Instead, you decide **every day** that you are going to consistently apply yourself to be the person you want to be. Sure, there is the *first time* that you decide, but it's not going to be the last so there's no need to throw a party.

If you want to succeed, decide publicly.

Telling your tribe that you're committing to a change is putting your back up against the wall. Eliminate the choice of fight or flight and simply fight until you win or fail. Your tribe will respect you for your honesty, if they don't, get a new one. Don't bother with people who don't support your destination. It's your journey, not theirs.

## The Journey

If you have committed to making the decision and you know where you're going, choose the path that takes you there.

Perhaps in your story there is great hardship and triumph. Wait, of course there is...it would be a boring story without this. In writing the story about your journey, you'll realize that all of the temptations of shortcuts that you face every day will likely make the story more remarkable when you overcome them or more boring when you give in. Being remarkable means that you will see good times and hard times. You will fail. But that isn't the end of the story.

Your journey is the story about the habits you mastered each and every day when you showed up and decided to be remarkable.

## The Destination

Where are you going?

'Get fit' isn't a destination, nor is 'be rich'. On the contrary to the management paradigm of SMART goals, being incredibly detailed about the results of your goals isn't that useful to help you decide on suitable destination.

Being specific with your goals is simply filtering the outcome you want through your expectations of what everyone else thinks of you. **Pick yourself**, and teach others to measure you the way you want to be measured.

Write yourself a story.

Imagine you are telling this story to a group of 2041 students in their final year of collage of perhaps business leaders from around the world. What is the destination that you reached that inspires them to listen to what you have to say? Perhaps this includes tangible metrics however the focus isn't on a number but the story that resonates with these people.

Your destination should enable you to tell this story, authentically and with great pride. 

**What is your story?**

posts.title: Start something. Now.
posts.markdown:
Starting something new is hard. A new exercise program, a startup, artwork, blog, song, app; it is always hard to start. When I talk about starting, I'm talking about more than thinking up concepts, designing logos or having meetings. I'm talking about jumping right into the hardest questions that scare you. Seth Godin describes this in **[The Dip](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1591841666/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1591841666)** and **[Poke the Box](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1936719002/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1936719002)** (Disclosure: both are affiliate links).

*Seth Godin would have to be my favorite author of all time. I feel a sense of enlightenment every time I read one of his books or listen to him talk. If you haven't had a taste of any of his work, subscribe to **[his blog](http://sethsblog.com/)***

Starting (the *real* starting) is not just hard, but is essential to ensure that we don't waste our time of projects that we should be quitting within hours or days of starting them. It's simply not worth creating an emotional sunk cost within a project and then later shying away from any difficult questions that could render the entire project dead. Address these questions early and either **be remarkable or quit.**

On some occasions, we fall off the wagon. In these times restarting is critical. Why? Because it is inevitable that we fall off sometimes and that we quit other times. There is such a great difference between falling off our strategy and quitting a project. When you fall off, you have a chance to change strategies, redefine your thinking and resume a healthy (but unknown) path towards completing the project. When you quit, you can't start again. You are starting a new project.

To get better at starting. Read [Poke the Box](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1936719002/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1936719002), it's shaped many of my thoughts on this issue. Better still, start something today.

I've created some rules for myself to help me stay focused. I thought it would be best to publicly share these so you can follow my progress throughout the blog:

1. Work on only **one** project at a time in the following fields: income, wealth, mind and body. (I'll describe these in an upcoming blog post soon)
2. Within 1 hour of starting the project, decide whether I'm going to be remarkable, or quit.
3. Set clear parameters for the project: What do I assume? What scares me? What is winning? What is failure?
4. Do not start a project until it's predecessor (in the same category) has been declared a victory or failure.
5. Create a daily video diary to keep myself accountable.

I'll be providing updates (and perhaps some video posts) as I follow these rules to let you know how effective they have been. This may not work, but that's okay with me.

posts.title: The story you tell yourself about entrepreneurship
posts.markdown:
Humans are funny creatures.

Admittedly, I love monkeys, however I'm sure they observe how we interact with our environment and think (with their little monkey brains) that we are weird and irrational. Although we proclaim that we are independent free-thinking beings, the reality is that mostly look for someone else to take the lead and everyone else just follows along.

I've always questioned whether entrepreneurs are more, or less rational than everyone else. In many cases we **don't** follow the general consensus, swim upstream (and across-stream) and get ourselves in bad situations, where *in retrospect* were led by clearly bad choices.

If we wanted the same out of life as everyone else but were trying to explore a new path, it's pretty irrational to think we would get the same result. (It **is** a new path after all!)

However conversely, not following the masses and forging a new path that wasn't laid out by someone before us seems like a smart thing to do if your ambitions are to live a non-conventional life.

And this is the lesson.

Starting from the perspective of understanding what you want your life to represent should determine which path you take. I'm not talking about setting goals. I'm not talking about a mission statement. This isn't even a question you need to answer right now, but you need to be aware of the question.

*What life do I want to create?*

I'm sure you recognise that if you do everything the same as everyone else and expect a different result, you're kidding yourself. However more often than not it's a case of a could-be entrepreneur who thinks that spending time drawing up lots of business plans is going to yield a different path. Unlikely.

If you want your life to be different, but you're not sure how, it doesn't mean you need to recreate everything yourself. Look for other people who have created a path for you to try. You don't need to innovate on every part of your life, but knowing when to follow and when to forge will be the key to unlocking your potential to focus on the things that matter to you the most.

Next time you see a pack of animals, spend a few minutes to watch them and choose who you think resembles the entrepreneur of the group. What do you notice about them? Are they the one trying to break free? Or maybe they are the one in the pack that comes up to you - the weird human, because you represent change and opportunity.

The story you tell yourself about these animals reflects the story you believe about entrepreneurship.

What story do you tell yourself?
posts.html:
Humans are funny creatures.

Admittedly, I love monkeys, however I'm sure they observe how we interact with our environment and think (with their little monkey brains) that we are weird and irrational. Although we proclaim that we are independent free-thinking beings, the reality is that mostly look for someone else to take the lead and everyone else just follows along.

I've always questioned whether entrepreneurs are more, or less rational than everyone else. In many cases we don't follow the general consensus, swim upstream (and across-stream) and get ourselves in bad situations, where in retrospect were led by clearly bad choices.

If we wanted the same out of life as everyone else but were trying to explore a new path, it's pretty irrational to think we would get the same result. (It is a new path after all!)

However conversely, not following the masses and forging a new path that wasn't laid out by someone before us seems like a smart thing to do if your ambitions are to live a non-conventional life.

And this is the lesson.

Starting from the perspective of understanding what you want your life to represent should determine which path you take. I'm not talking about setting goals. I'm not talking about a mission statement. This isn't even a question you need to answer right now, but you need to be aware of the question.

What life do I want to create?

I'm sure you recognise that if you do everything the same as everyone else and expect a different result, you're kidding yourself. However more often than not it's a case of a could-be entrepreneur who thinks that spending time drawing up lots of business plans is going to yield a different path. Unlikely.

If you want your life to be different, but you're not sure how, it doesn't mean you need to recreate everything yourself. Look for other people who have created a path for you to try. You don't need to innovate on every part of your life, but knowing when to follow and when to forge will be the key to unlocking your potential to focus on the things that matter to you the most.

Next time you see a pack of animals, spend a few minutes to watch them and choose who you think resembles the entrepreneur of the group. What do you notice about them? Are they the one trying to break free? Or maybe they are the one in the pack that comes up to you - the weird human, because you represent change and opportunity.

The story you tell yourself about these animals reflects the story you believe about entrepreneurship.

What story do you tell yourself?

posts.title: 3 phases of hacking my life
posts.markdown:
**Synopsis**: we limit ourselves by constraints. Some of these constraints are imposed by the environment we live in, but most are imposed by our own reactions to our environment.**Brief**: Design this week, day by day, assuming that you are completely free of every constraint that you could imagine would stop you from doing those things. The only rule is that it must be humanly possible (no growing wings and flying unless you have a connection to a stem-cell research lab). Include things you would have, skills you would learn, activities you would do.

**Monday (starting at midday)**

* Ride over to The Rocks in Sydney and climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge
* Charter an aeroplane from Sydney out to Sydney's Northern Beaches
* Jump on a harbour dinner cruise around Sydney Harbour, eating amazing food and drink red wine
* Stop off into the iMax cinemas for a big-screen movie

**Tuesday**

* Wake up at 6am and attend a yoga class
* Swim 1km at the local pool to cool down from Yoga
* Drop in at the Charlotte's Cafe Birchgrove for a yogurt and muesli breakfast (with coffee of course)
* Meet up with my Dad and ride my bike up to the local Triumph motorcycle dealer. Take out the Triumph Tiget 800 and Explorer for a few hours. Buy the one I like the most.
* Have lunch with my family in a local Balmain cafe.
* See the local real estate agent with my wife to inspect 3 of our favourite properties in Birchgrove/Balmain. Purchase the one that we like the most.
* Head on over to the Apple Store Sydney and purchase a MacBook Pro Retina to replace my current MacBook.
* Celebrate by going out to dinner on Darling Harbour.
* Book a ticket to Singapore for the next day

**Wednesday**

* Book Uber to get to the airport.
* Spend time in the business lounge before flight departs. Post on blog, check in on other businesses.
* Take first class flight with Singapore Airlines, ordering everything that looks yummy on the menu.
* Arrive in Singapore and book into a 5-star hotel on Orchard Ave.
* Go out for dinner and relax in the city skyline with a bottle of wine.

**Thursday**

* Go for a swim in the hotel's pool and eat a buffet breakfast.
* Buy some comfortable shoes and begin a 1 day clothing shopping spree in the city with my wife
* Head back to the place where we bought our wedding rings and get them cleaned and polished (complimentary!)
* Catch the MRT up to Kembangan and go for a Wake-board on the pond on east-cast park.
* Walk to Kassim for a cheap dinner at the place where we always ate the last time we were here.
* Head to an exhibition within the city for the night, make a last minute decision where we will go and just do it.
* Book a flight to Bangkok for the next day.

**Friday**

* Fly first class to Bangkok early in the morning
* Book into a 5-star hotel near Siam Pargon
* Get a 2-hour whole body message
* Eat out on the streets in Bangkok for lunch
* Go shopping in Siam Pargon to see what we can find
* Book in for a dinner cruise on the Bangkok river for the evening
* Enjoy whatever festivities are on in the city for Friday night. Make a last-minute decision and do it.

**Saturday**

* Wake up and catch the Skytrain to the JJ Cuttuchuk markets.
* Eat, buy funky clothes, get foot messages (because walking gets painful) for a few hours.
* Visit a courier and put all of our new purchases into a box to send back to Sydney.
* Catch a First-class Emirates flight back to Sydney in the afternoon
* Crash out for a good night sleep back in Sydney

**Sunday**

* Wake up and attend a Yoga class.
* Swim 1km at the Dawn Fraser Baths to cool down
* Eat breakfast at charlotte's cafe
* Compile photos and videos from the week into a video using Final Cut Pro
* Go for a ride down to see my parents (and Rosy) on my new bike.
* Eat a long lunch with the family and share stories of the week.
* Blog about the week, and what I found Remarkable along my journey.

Sleep

**Recap** - What did I learn?

Writing this post took three phases of my emotions:

Phase 1: Getting started - "What the hell would I do? I'm used to having constraints!"
Phase 2: Getting into it - "This is kinda fun! Spin the wheel and that's what I'm doing!"
Phase 3: Reviewing - "I could actually do 80% of this, and most of it is cheap!"

Phase 1

The reason I went through this exercise is to experiment with breaking the habit of self-imposed constraints. We put constraints on ourselves because it's safe and we are addicted to avoiding uncertainty. For example, if you were going to choose a restaurant to eat at tonight, most people will either:

a) limit their choices by the *good* restaurants that they have been to before (2 constraints: have been to, and good), or

b) they will limit choices by region, cuisine, price or dietary preferences.

Why do we do this?

1. It's simply too hard to choose from such a large list. *Picking correctly requires logic.*
2. It's a safer bet picking 1 in 5 instead of 1 in 500. *The stakes are too high, we might just not enjoy the meal.*
3. If the food sucks, it couldn't be *our* fault because we chose the best we could. *We hate being wrong.*

However consider the times when you felt on top of the world, when you achieved your best work, when you do things that are remarkable (for yourself and others). Typically, in these cases:

* We use more heart than logic.
* The stakes are high, that's why it's remarkable.
* We could have been wrong, but we picked a winner.

In phase 1 of this exercise, I worked out that there was so much holding me back. The voice in my head was telling me to play safe, to not think of anything too crazy. Yes, this is the Lizard Brain, a concept introduced to me by Seth Godin. Its prehistoric protectionist tendencies were eating at me to make a safe bet.

Phase 2

Once the initial thoughts of 'This might not work' diminished, I was enjoying thinking of all the things I would do. The fun part is putting yourself in the shoes of a billionaire or super-fast learner or super-fit athlete. Then you ask the question: 'Now that the money/money has been taken care of. What's next?'.

I kept this experiment true to my personality. Am I the sort of guy who goes out and spends a million dollars at a casino? No, I morally dislike gambling and simply wouldn't do it. Would I fly first class around the world? Yes I would.

Phase 3

Now looking back through my list, I'm a bit surprised at how many things were relatively cheap (under $100) to complete. Which inspired some 80:20 analysis on my behalf to work out what dreams are holding back my current happiness. Let's look at a list of things that cost money vs are cheap.

[Climb the harbour bridge](http://www.bridgeclimb.com/Price/standard-price/) - $436 (2 people)

[Charter an aeroplane](http://www.seaplanes.com.au/menu-of-services/scenic-flights/) - $530 (2 people)

[Harbour cruise](http://www.captaincook.com.au/home.asp?pageid=1661F5DD27C61DDC&destinationid=55F0AB3672931FB9&cruiseid=BEBC47A6291DC688) - $418 (Gold - 2 people)

[iMax](http://www.imax.com.au/home/) - $43 (2 people)

Yoga x 2 - $10

Swim x 2 - $8

Breakfast for 2 at the cafe x 2 - $100

Test ride motorbike - free

Buy Motorbike - $20k

New home - $1m

MacBook Pro Retina - $3500

Dinner on darling harbour - $150

Uber car rental - $30

Business lounge - Complimentary

Flight to Singapore - $7800 (2 people)

Dinner in Singapore - $150 (fancy-ish dinner)

Hotel for 2 nights - $714

Shopping spree in Singapore - $5000

Wake Boarding - $20

Cheap meal in Kassim - $10

Night out in Singapore - $200

Flight to Bangkok - $2000

Hotel for 1 night - $600

2-hour massage - $10

Eat on the streets of Bangkok - $10 (for a lot of food!)

Shopping in Siam - $1000

Dinner cruise - $100

JJ Markets shopping - $300

Shipping to Australia - $100 (lots of stuff)

Flight to Sydney - $6280

Create my own weekly movie $0

Launch with family $0

Blogging $0

**Total weekly cost = $1,049,529**

Now, there are 33 things to do on this list. Three of which are asset purchases (house, bike and MacBook Pro), that have a residual value even after purchase. Let's leave them out of the analysis.

Total weekly cost = $26,029

From this number, we can break out the top 2 things that drive 85% of the cost:

Flights - $16,080

Shopping - $6,300

Total weekly cost without these = $5,649 (but add $2000 for reasonable flights and $1000 total shopping)

**Now, here is the insight: from my 'dream week', 26 of the 33 things could be achieved for 25% of the total cost.**

**The lesson**

I see that I'm holding onto the more expensive things (the things that constrain me now) as reasons for not doing almost everything else. It's time for some hacking.

Next post: Hacking dreams to reality.

Feel free to add your thoughts below.

posts.title: Meaning Trumps Form
posts.markdown:
Today we are faced with an overwhelming number of tips, strategies and tactics to achieve whatever we want to achieve. The biggest problem is that these are pushed to us by both respected (and some unknown) content marketers and businesses. More likely, they are pushed to us when we aren't ready to hear it.

We have all tried it - keeping thousands of bookmarks, white papers and ebooks, all promising to change our lives, but we never get to reading (let alone, acting upon) 10% them. If you try gobble down *10 SEO strategies for your blog* when you're just finding your voice, you risk focusing on **form over meaning.** Form is about tactics, numbers, optimisation and winning. Meaning is about venerability, connection, having something to say and creating art. 

## MEANING ALWAYS TRUMPS FORM.

When faced with an abundance of information on how to improve my every aspect of my business and my life, I'm looking for people to trust instead of guides to follow (even if those guides are free).

### People who have earned my trust

* [Pat Flynn](http://smartpassiveincome.com/)
* [Seth Godin](http://sethgodin.com/)
* [Tim Ferriss](http://www.fourhourworkweek.com/blog/)
* [Chris Guillibeau](http://chrisguillebeau.com/)

This list grows over time. It has replaced my list of 1000 resources that promised to change my life but never did because I wasn't ready for them. Now when I have an online marketing problem, I'll check out [Pat at Smart Passive Income](http://smartpassiveincome.com/). When I am in need of inspiration,[ I'll read Seth](http://sethgodin.com/). When I feel like hacking my life, [Tim shows up](http://www.fourhourworkweek.com/blog/). When I'm looking for a role model to restore trust in the movement I'm creating,[Chris is around.](http://chrisguillebeau.com/)

**Meaning trumps form every time.**

Meaning trumps form every time.

posts.title: English, my arrogant first language
posts.markdown:
I'm a native English speaker. Most people in the world will — or will be expected to — listen to my words and discern my commands. Few will understand me.

You might be quick to judge the implicit arrogance of such a statement. Not withstanding criticism, I believe the collective expectation to meet with English as a cross-cultural *common ground* disadvantages native English speakers.

Language can be learned, yet we perceive and experience **our** world in a single language. This is not to say that one cannot perceive **the** *world* in multiple languages. But each idea, connection, sensation, and place exists in a single realm of understanding, and therefore a single language.

Being a native English speaker is often considered a blessing. Taking the perspective of a merchant, explorer, or diplomat, this is indeed a blessing. More productivity, more progress, new and exciting opportunities. A universal language makes it easy to trade, negotiate, and get things done. Beyond survival and progress it doesn't help us understand people.

Might we ponder the opposite? What are the disadvantages of English has your first, and perhaps only, language?

posts.title: THE VALUE OF YOUR ATTENTION
posts.markdown:
You're reading this post. For just one moment you're giving me the gift of your attention. From my heart, thank you!

I **know** that you're not here because I bought your attention with advertising. Although you likely are here because you know me personally or someone has told you about this blog. However my wish is that you're not here for me, but for you.

But less about me, here are two people who have earned my trust and respect.

* * *

## Pat Flynn

I really enjoy listening to [Pat Flynn's Smart Passive Income podcast.](http://www.smartpassiveincome.com/category/podcast/)  Pat is an artist. He puts his heart into creating something new, unique and insanely valuable for his readers and listeners. Above all, what makes Pat remarkable is that he values your attention. He invests so much time into the small details that make us feel appreciated and valued. When you write an email to Pat, he writes back.  In fact, I gave Pat permission to use an email that I wrote to him in a testimonial for his new Snippit project 'Let Go' [here.](http://patflynn.me/praise/)

* * *


## Chris Brogan

[Chris Brogan](http://www.chrisbrogan.com/) has an agreement with his readers. He will preface an email with a message that contains the words "Selly Sell". 

Chris has described why he does it [here.](http://www.chrisbrogan.com/sellysell/)

However it's very simple: he has set the ground rules with his readers. This happens in the very first email after you subscribe to his list:

>*Please note: if I intend to sell you something, I’ll be VERY clear about it. Humorously clear. I’ll label that PITCHY PITCH SELLY SELL or something like this. (This drives marketers nuts.) Yep. There’s never going to be a mystical or secret tricky sale hidden anywhere. I’ll let you know.*

This is what this message means to me: **Even if you're not interested in buying from me, I still want you in my tribe so I'm going to make our relationship easy and transparent. You can trust me.**

* * *

## A note from me

When you create art, permission is the essential ingredient to build trust with your tribe. Growing true fans happens one person at a time. It's not about going viral, it's not about a database or email list. You can't buy true fans. You earn them.

If you're still reading this, you have donated your attention to me for a few minutes. When you started reading this post, you trusted me to write something valuable. Something useful. Something worth sharing. Something remarkable.

If you feel this way, I'm not going to ask you to buy anything. Instead, sharing this post on Facebook, Twitter or Google+ would mean the world to me (easy links below). However if this blog isn't for you, that's okay with me. I'm thankful that you took the time to read up until now.

If you feel this way, I'm not going to ask you to buy anything. Instead, sharing this post on Facebook, Twitter or Google+ would mean the world to me (easy links below). However if this blog isn't for you, that's okay with me. I'm thankful that you took the time to read up until now.

posts.title: Perfect = failure
posts.markdown:
Time has passed, you're finally done, it's now *perfect* ...sorry, you've just failed.

Although we often think that perfect is the end goal, I believe that sometimes it should be seen as failure - trying to **maximize** rather than **optimize.**

We have gone through life with people telling us that we need to aim for perfect. For me, I see that perfect induces, or rather demands, opportunity loss. If we apply the rules of the Pareto Principle (80/20), this opportunity loss is significant. To achieve the last 20% (or even the last 10% in some cases) of results for a project to be perfect, you will spend 80% of the total time on the project allocated to achieving this final small improvement.

Think of this in terms of becoming an elite athlete, speaker, publisher, community worker, student. The final 20% of success to become the best in the world comes at a cost - 80% of your time that could have been allocated to achieving other goals. Is this a bad thing?

This has been a consistent battle for me over many years. On one hand, we have the amazing thoughts and insights from Seth's [The Dip,](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1591841666/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1591841666) and on the other we have Tim's [The 4-hour Work week](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0307465357/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0307465357). There are times when being the best in the world is the only option if we want to make a difference. However, this doesn't necessarily need to be income-related. Perhaps, you'll use the principles from the 4HWW to generate passive income while you chase your true passion of being the most proactive environmentalist on the planet? It's up to you.

Ask yourself the following questions:

1. Do I need to be remarkable? *(If yes, head towards The Dip first and then come back to the 4HWW)*

2. Can I allocate a smaller portion of my undivided attention (days or weeks) for this project to be successful?

Both books are going to be valuable compasses on your journey however it's important to work out in **which order** you need to consider them. Being the best in the world may not be a great path if you're not prepared to invest the time to push through the Dip. If you still want to ship the project, go for 80/20.

Let's pull away from projects and just talk about life. Answer these questions honestly. If your answer sounds like an excuse, try again.

1. Why do you start at work at 6/7/8/9 and finish at 3/4/5/6? **Why?**
2. Would you rather donate your time or money to charitable causes? **Is this an excuse for doing neither?**
3. What are you really saving for? **Why can someone do without it but you need it?**
4. Do you really need to own stuff? **What's wrong with renting or borrowing it when you need to use it?**
5. If you only could spend 1 day at work per week, what would you **stop** doing? **Stop it!**

posts.title: Are you hand wrapped and delivered on a bicycle?
posts.markdown:
Physical products are delivered in physical ways. You could ship a product using the postal service, a highly efficient FedEX courier, or perhaps by a man in a top-hat riding a bicycle.

**Delivery is an experience** 

Wind back 100 years and the  product options were to be hand delivered by the artist, delivered by a servant, delivered by someone of significance or the delivered by the postal cart. The method chosen required some thought. First impressions count, right?

In this world of human connection and online transactions, delivery still matters. No, in fact it's the delivery experience that matters.

* When you deliver a presentation, are you hand wrapping your content and creating an experience for your audience? Or are you making generic slides, reading notes and not engaging your audience?
* When people sign up for your email list do they receive a warm welcome and thank you? Or is the generic *'click here to confirm your email'* message the first thing that they receive from you ?
* When you're building your connections on LinkedIn, are you customizing the invitation *(think of a handwritten letter instead of a generic invitation)* and following up to offer your assistance?

These three examples each illustrate a different aspect in today's social connection economy that many people misunderstand: assumed lock-in, incognito, social accounting.

## Assumed Lock-In

When someone turns up to your presentation, they sit down and listen. Perhaps they have even paid money (or are being paid hourly) to sit there. It's not etiquette to stand up and leave a presentation (although most presentations are bad.) However in the connection economy, our attention is the commodity we trade. If we don't like your presentation, people will start checking their email. If you're really boring, I can now tweet that it sucks and more than just that room knows. You can't lock everyone in, therefore lock no one.

## Incognito

Everyone is undercover. We can give fake names and sudo-email addresses when we sign up to an email list or buy a product and it's totally acceptable. You may get tens of thousands people signup to your list, buy your product or use your service. They don't provide their true details because they don't trust you. **Build trust.** Don't sell to people who don't trust you. Build trust, then ship. Set expectations and live up to them. Offer your help and deliver it. Create a remarkable experience from the delivery of everything.

## Social Accounting

I no longer need to remember your name, your wife's name, your dog's name or your passion at work. Facebook and LinkedIn does is for me. Sure, it's efficient, but it allows people to build a database of connections (Facebook calls these '*friends*' and Twitter calls them '*followers*', but they are neither) instead of a network of true fans. Social accounting is now in a social CRM instead of our minds and hearts. The problem is that most people use the social accounting tools to become the lonely person connected to everyone but respected by no one. Instead, use the tools to deliver the best of you to your true fans. Disconnect from people who aren't in your tribe and don't believe in you. Learn the art of being social instead of just the tactics of being social.

**The art of creating a remarkable delivery experience is the foundation of building your tribe of true fans.**

posts.title: I choose the world I live in
posts.markdown:
The title of this post was going to be 'I want to live in a world where…'

But I don't believe it's wishful thinking that will take me there. It's perception, acceptance and filtering.

Let's not hide, there is so much of this world that doesn't work. There is poverty in the richest and poorest countries, we're consuming more resources than we have available for our grandchildren, and political self-interest writes the rules of the game (for most).

There are numerous global problems, some more urgent than others, that we can concern ourselves with. Most people love to talk about these. They watch the news and feel it's their job to inform others, take sides and voice their opinion. Sorry, democracy isn't about your opinion, it's about what you do.

What you choose to do begins with a thought and ends when you ship your ideas as work, art, emotional labour. The goal isn't to simply have more thoughts and take the shortcut to tell everyone your opinion. No, the goal is to do something remarkable that demonstrates your beliefs about this world. We want you to create art and change other people's minds about a cause that you're passionate about. It doesn't matter if this is a commercial interest: you'e passionate about hiring out clowns to make people smile, or a social interest: protecting logging in the Amazon. In fact I don't care about your belief, I care about the remarkable experience that you create so I can share your story with others.

We have opinions and tell stories. Every day, we intersect with the world through our opinions and our stories. That's it. No matter whether it's person-to-person communication or from an organisation, you will hear someone's opinion or their story. The latter has the potential for a great conversation, the former is boring and predictable.

Opinions + actions = stories.

* We don't care what food you like. I'd love to hear about a restaurant that made you think differently about eating.
* We don't care if you believe we should better support the poor. I'd love to understand what the impact is for a child when they are supported by a program that you create.
* We don't care if your product is lighter, faster, cheaper. I'd love to know how the designers and engineers worked together to build an amazing product.

I choose to live in a world where…

- Things may not work and I will fail.
- I will be judged.
- Success is measured by the proportion of lives I change each day.
- I'm true to myself.
- Life is a series of projects, nothing is forever.
- People I love will pass on.
- I will be inspired.
- How I feel is determined by me.
- Time is not money, and there is no exchange rate where it becomes equitable.

**Perception is how my opinion becomes my art.**

**Filtering is required to eliminate opinions without stories.**

**Acceptance of failure eliminates my fear of the world judging me.**

posts.title: We all get lost
posts.markdown:
It happens to all of us.

We get lost on our journey, but it's not because we don't know where we are going. Sometimes we put blame on 'not knowing what I want' or 'not knowing where I want to be'. However this isn't particularly true nor useful. 

Instead, I believe that most of us know **exactly**  where we want to go but we are scared of admitting it. If we tell people, they might hold us accountable. If I fail, they will know.

No, you know exactly where you want to go, but from time to time you look around and see other people who seem to have *made it* . You look at them and question whether you have what it takes, whether you are worthy of what they have.

Here's the paradox: the clearer you are about where you want to go, you're more likely to fall into the trap of questioning your path, your tactics, your execution. 

I could suggest to follow your heart, but you're already doing that. 

[Stay hungry, stay foolish.](http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/post/steve-jobs-told-students-stay-hungry-stay-foolish/2011/10/05/gIQA1qVjOL_blog.html)

posts.title: The expectation gap
posts.markdown:
Creating remarkable experiences is surprisingly easy to understand. All you need to remember is that **how someone feels is the difference between their expectations and reality.** It's really that simple.

If you're given a pay rise, you'll still be disappointed if your pay is a day late.
*The additional pay is ignored because it was expected to be on time.*

If your customers expect a routine transaction and you honor them with attention, you will be remarkable.
*Break someone's schema of the world and they'll fell that they must tell other people.*

If your customer was told in an email campaign that a 15% discount would be applied but the checkout only calculated a 10% discount, they will be more upset then appreciative.
*Even if they they were prepared to pay full price, you got them excited and let them down.*

If you promise an eBook and deliver an exclusive Youtube channel, your tribe will find people to tell.
*Now they're an insider. They got a bonus that only insiders get. They want their friends to become insiders too.*

posts.title: Trust, and you shall be remarkable.
posts.markdown:
Trust in business is a rare characteristic: we often say that we trust you, but don't ever let you show us whether we should. Many business owners/managers fall short by their limited perception of the how trust creates a remarkable customer experience.

Picture this scenario: you go to two restaurants in the one day, one where you a welcomed, seated on the front strip where you are excluded from the restaurant noise and you could easily get up and walk away. The waitress doesn't ask for any money up front and will provide you with all of the food and wine that takes your fancy. At the end you will be given a bill, which you pay (and likely tip).

The other restaurant only allows you to order from the front counter and you must pay before they submit the order, call out your number and then you sit down with your food. Each drink you order must be bought at the bar and paid for on the spot. There is nothing particularly wrong with the second restaurant, it just will never be a remarkable experience.

That's it, people will make a recommend you to others and likely share, tweet, like, the place when they feel like they are being trusted. If your businesses relies on word of mouth, this is incredibly important. Try to answer the following questions:

1) What if you said to your customers "we'll bill you tomorrow if you wake up and are still happy with the purchase/service"?

2) What if you asked your customers to pay what THEY thought the products are worth, depending on their satisfaction level?

3) What really would be the losses if you trusted your customers more?

The aim isn't to minimize loses, the aim is for your customers to first trust you, then tell their friends.

posts.title: If only...
posts.markdown:
…is a cop out.

When you start with *If only,* you are telling me that you're not good enough. Good enough is easy to find. Others, just like you, have more money, better qualifications, more powerful connections. But I don't care about them.

I care about you because you have my attention in this very moment. What are you going to do with it?

Right now, you are connecting with me. Right now, you have an opportunity to make me feel something.

You could do something predictable. You could play it safe and do something that I won't notice and i'll likely ignore you. However being anonymous doesn't scale. Someone will catch you out and either like what you do, what you say, how you act, or perhaps they won't. In a sure-bet that you can't hide forever, now is your chance to do step out. Do something that frightens you and maybe, just maybe will astound me.

In this very moment, you can't change your wealth, resources, connections. You CAN however, change the way I feel. Not change the way I feel about you, change the way I feel about myself in this world. You can do that.

A remarkable experience is one I'll never forget.

posts.title: Success and the Vacuum of Influence
posts.markdown:
Understanding social standing is hard.

There is a particular part of your brain that is responsible for social processing, it's called the Amygdala.

Putting all science aside *(My wife often tells me I'm the entrepreneur guy not the scientist....)*  there is something we to know about social processing - it influences the way we think and most of us can't work out why.

I've recently been reading [Jonah Berger's book](http://amzn.to/126YoFr) [Contagious](http://amzn.to/126YoFr). Even though I haven't finished yet, I was intrigued by Jonah's reference to the Harvard case study that gave students two options:

1. A job where they made $50,000 per year, or
2. A job where they made $100,000 per year. 

The catch is that there was additional information to each situation. In the first situation the student would be getting paid*twice* as much as others around them (who would be on $25,000 per year), where in the second situation they would be paid *half*  of what everyone else was being paid ($200,000). Which did the majority of people choose? **Option A - $50,000.  That's NUTS!**

## Is our measure of success *relative* to those around us?

Perhaps so. How can we break ourselves away from this desire? Reading [Tim's 4-hour Workweek](http://amzn.to/12Ic9rB), I recall the moment when Tim pointed out that you're the average of the five people you spend most of your time with. I really need to emphasise this:

> You are the average of the five people you spend most of your time with.

Let's call this the 'Vacuum of influence', where you're likely to get *pulled* in the direction of those people who influence you the most. This was an extraordinary insight and me and extremely useful when I catch myself choosing *Option A *over*Option B.* Although human social tendencies want us to be the 'top-dog' instead of the 'underdog', the true entrepreneurial spirit demands that we spend time with people who are more successful than we are.

### What to do around people of influence.

Show your work.  Be proud, your work is your art.

Share your opinions. Say something new.

Listen to stories. 

Work out **very**  quickly whether you want to be on the same path as these people. If you don't decide, you'll eventually be just like them. For better or for worse.

posts.title: Freelancer or Entrepreneur? Seth Godin cares and so should you
posts.markdown:
In my recent post [25 insights from Seth Godin’s Startup School,](http://beingremarkable.me/blog/25-insights-from-seth-godins-startup-school) my first insight was deciding whether you are a freelancer or entrepreneur. Although the difference is subtle, the impact of thinking you’re one type and acting like the other guarantees almost certain failure.

### Are you a freelancer?

Who hires you? If sending your protégé would result in your client being unhappy, you’re a freelancer. People hire you because you’re amazing at what you do. Perhaps they don’t have the guts to make decisions about what’s next or you are creating something new because it’s been identified as important.

Now you know you’re a freelancer, recognize that you’re the centre of someone’s universe at the point when they need you, but you won’t be needed forever. Times change and whatever you’re the best at today must evolve or you won’t get a call tomorrow.

If there is too much demand for your work, you can’t hire someone just like you and share the load. People are hiring you, not them. This may even work a few times but the business will fail because the person who is being hired for their incredible work (you) is also the person who needs to sell your reputation to new clients. The endless loop of trying to find new clients to keep the payroll running will take all of your time and you won’t have any hours left to be the brilliant person that you need to be.

This may sound familiar if you are a freelancer working more than 80 hours per week.

You’ll also notice that many successful accounting and law firms typically build a brand where the client is no longer hiring ‘John Smith’ but they’re hiring Deloitte or PwC. If John was to leave and expect to charge $1000 per hour from the same clients, he’ll soon find out that they didn’t care so much about John but the ability to hide behind the name: "But Deloitte said it was a good idea!"

The original partners successfully transitioned from freelancers to entrepreneurs. This is rare, not many do.

### What is an entrepreneur?

Where a freelancer is the singer in the act, the entrepreneur is the agent who makes it a show. A singer could be soloist, a duet or front a band, but it’s the agent who makes the action happen. The agent wants to assemble the best artists to deliver an experience to an audience she understands. If a member of the act is sick, she’ll even try step in and take their place, but she’s not the act. She has a commitment to putting on the type of show that she believes will resonate with the audience. When she fails and the audience doesn’t show up and tell their friends she looks for another audience.

Entrepreneurship isn’t about you. It’s about what you create. Your art is the living organism that we call a business. It connects people with a cause and you inspire confidence in the movement when everyone doubts you. You probably do this by telling stories.

Someone once described the bi-polar ups and downs that we entrepreneurs feel as similar to a pendulum. Sometimes it feels things are positive and only getting better, then all of a sudden, the world is against us, and then it’s not again. The skill is realizing that the reality is that the pendulum is almost still to the outside world, it’s the voice inside our head that makes it swing.

### Can I be both?

Sure, but not on the same project. But the real question is: why do you need to be both? Every freelancer and entrepreneur that I know wishes they had more time to work on their project and to be the best they can be. Perhaps you’re not sure whether your project will work. In this case, hedging your bets will only make it more risky rather than make it safer. Choose, quickly.

### What about you Todd?

*I've added two others categories.*

**Investor** - I’m an investor in Apathco Group. I no longer show up every day and do the hard work that my team does. Three years ago, I wore every hat: sales guy, marketing guy, operations guy, admin guy...some of these I was better at than others but the business was only as good as me on my good days. The entrepreneurial pendulum impacted my business because the business was tied to my emotional wellbeing. This wasn’t fair to my team who had the passion to step up and take ownership of their work. So I took a step back and defined myself as an investor.

**Entrepreneur** - I’m an entrepreneur in my latest startup Referron. There’s no salary, my equity is earned from sweat and my role has changed from designer to developer to project manager and who knows what’s next? We’re building the business to be bigger than the founders. We’re building the community for our customers but we’re not always going to be around to moderate - we'll build a team for that.

**Freelancer** - When someone hires me to speak, that’s me as a freelancer. I’m trading effort for a benefit that only they could provide me. This could be money but could also be exposure to their community.

**Artist** - You’re reading my art, perhaps you listen to it too? It’s only as polished as I want and when I receive feedback, it’s my choice to take it on board or not. I don’t need the world to love me or my ideas, but those who do have my heart and mind forever. Your attention is valuable and I hope that I’ve earned it. Each day that I show up, you have a choice to listen or not. I’m still showing up. As an artist, I hope that you tell your friends if you think that I’m worthy of their attention (and your credibility) too. If not, that’s okay.

[Listen to the Startup School podcast in iTunes here.](https://itunes.apple.com/au/podcast/seth-godins-startup-school/id566985370)

posts.title: Changing Perceptions
posts.markdown:
You could be kind to everyone you meet. If you stop reading now, just do this. Alas, we are selfish. We spend most of our lives thinking about survival — pleasure seeking, pain reducing, fear defining — for ourselves, or people *like us*.

It's difficult to reconcile our compassion for certain types of people and not for others. Most people recognise that compassion and empathy demands that we don't discriminate who it is for.

Being kind to everyone is hard. Removing the shackles of judgment from years of cultural reinforcement is much harder.

Yet, being kind becomes much easier when you travel from your home country.

You are now the outsider. People will judge **you** upon on the way you speak, dress, and the way you glance at everyone else like a nervous child. At this precise moment you represent the entire stereotype, open for reinforcement or destruction.

Being kind to everyone is hard. I'm not speaking about making small-talk and being pleasant in an elevator. Kindness is doing the uncomfortable, unexpected, and compassionate things that someone is compelled to tell another about.

When travelling, be kind to the old lady who can't speak English. Be kind to the teenager with a point to prove. Be kind to the maid who is expecting to be treated like a servant.

You'll make their day. More importantly, you will challenge their stereotype of *people like you*, and might just tell someone else to not be afraid.

posts.title: About Todd
posts.markdown:
Hi I'm Todd, it's pretty fun being me. I'm a loving husband and entrepreneur turned small-time angel investor. I love to see remarkable people work on remarkable projects and make a difference in the lives they care about. It happens every day, in my city and in yours. This blog is about capturing these moments.
![Todd](https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/beingremarkable/2016/10/Todd-Image-1.png)
### Maybe we're similar.
Or maybe we're not, that's okay too. You see, I think differently to other entrepreneurs you may have met. Although this has worked in my favour, I deeply hope that my perspective might help you too. Do you care about deepening your relationships with your customers? Read on.

Starting from a young age, I've built online and offline businesses, made lots of mistakes, had a few extraordinary wins and have the battle wounds to make your ride a little smoother. I try not to preach or rant but I'm passionate about helping people to settle for nothing less than being remarkable.

I've worked with a select handful of the world's top companies (Ernst & Young, Apple etc) as well as the smallest unknown startups. The value I create is very simple - I narrow my involvement down to one question.

>How does your business build, analyse and deepen intimate relationships with your most passionate customers?

Some people call this strategy, others call it customer development. It's what I do best. Outside of my online projects where I have a broader impact, I only consult with clients who I believe have the right mindset to truly deepen their customer relationships. If this isn't you, that's okay maybe we're not right for each other. If this is you, I can help you with a framework and principles to truly build long lasting value in your business.

If you're not sure where to start, you can subscribe to my email list. I'll be in touch and we'll take things from there. Otherwise, you can [directly contact me here](/contact).

Thanks for dropping by, I hope to meet you sometime.

-- Todd

posts.title: When people stare
posts.markdown:
Say hello.

This was wise reminder given to me by my wife. Sometimes we feel a sense of anxiety in situations when we are centre of attention. The human mind can turn a completely benign social interaction into a torment of the mind in seconds. Unfortunently, some people live with an illness that brings this on everyday. For most of us, we can control how we feel when we are expectedly (e.g. public speaking) or unexpectedly (e.g. in a foreign cultural environment) centre of attention. Here are three tips towards controlling the anxiety of being centre of attention.

**Say 'Hello'.** This brings our mind to the present, moving from thoughts of *'what if?'* and *'I know what they're thinking'* to a real interaction between our mind and the world around us.

**Pause.** Too often we rush to finish what we're doing when we're fearful that people are judging us, waiting upon our failure and ready to shame us. This fear, like any other fear, can be overcome if we pause and take a moment to realize that we have complete control on the situation. Every word, movement, gesture, tonal change is ours. We own it. Everyone else is a passive bystander until we let them into **our** world.

**Smile.** Someone will smile back. Nothing is better for the soul (and your confidence).

*If you forget what smiling looks like, here is an example.*

posts.title: The curse of convenience
posts.markdown:
**Being convenient or cheap makes you reactive to people who want you to be exactly that.**

When you set up your store in a large shopping centre or below a new development of the headquarters of a global bank, you are *guaranteed* new customers. This is considered smart business sense right? - There is a guaranteed supply of customers coming through your doors simply because you're convenient. Unfortunately, now you're in the game of reaction and manipulation. 

There's nothing particularly wrong with the game of reaction and manipulation, but it's not for me. You can have excellent decor, an interesting menu (or variety of products) and of course a great location, but you're not likely to be remarkable. You'll need to run specials and discounts and you'll probably pretend that these returning customers are loyal. Worst of all, you will likely listen to the rude customer's feedback, simply because they're paying your bills.

It's not likely that you're going to be that place where people cross the city to show their friends. Maybe, but unlikely.

The lesson isn't to position yourself out of town where you're not convenient. The lesson is to **first** provide a remarkable experience and create an environment where stories are born and shared between friends. Once you have this, your location can be optimised...but it may not even need to.

A great location is a fixed cost that guarantees customers that you probably don't want to serve. Instead of 10,000 customers who return only when they *need*  to (or when you have a 50% special running), it's better to be in the game of serving your 1000 true fans. Now you need to exert *emotional labor* , not just the *physical labor*  of working 80-hour weeks. You must reach out and change the lives of those people who return because they *want to.*

A location doesn't just mean physical location. It's any fixed cost that you incur to reduce risk but distracts you from making your art and connecting with people. For example:

* A booth at a generic trade show, just because your competitors are there.
* An advertisement on TV to absolutely everyone.
* Polishing a website with no visitors. 

...now your turn. What else? (leave comments below)

posts.title: The story I tell myself, and the story I tell others
posts.markdown:
There is a local store near me called['The Source'](https://www.facebook.com/TheSourceBulkFoods), where they sell over 350 products including nuts, seeds, grains, cereals, flour, rice, honey, oils, confectionary and snacks. The catch - the entire store is lined with white tubs and you serve yourself in brown paper bags.

What makes *The Source* remarkable is the story that they create.

## The story I tell myself

Walking into a store and finding hundreds of raw foods in clean white tubs excites me. Despite the fact that there are lots of sweets and snacks, it's still truly like being a kid in a lolly shop.  If you ask any of my friends, they'll agree that the following totally fits my personality:

* Browsing hundreds of nuts, seeds, grains, and cereals. (And buying something weird)
* Choosing what I want and scooping it myself to the quantity that I need.
* Buying organic dark chocolate in messy chunks. 
* Reusing my oil bottle and selecting different types of oil from a range of drums. 
* Buying the exact ingredients to make a cake (weighing it in the shop).
* Shopping with no plastic required. 

### The story I tell others

What make *The Source*  truly remarkable is the story I tell others. "Hey you still going to a mass department store to buy your groceries? You gotta try this!" There will be people who simply don't want to trust their own sense of what to purchase. They rather buy what they have always bought or what is on special for the week. It's okay if they don't show up.

What makes the story special is that it makes me  feel good telling people that I shop at *The Source* . I'm *that*  kind of guy and shops there.

posts.title: Accumulation or Aggregation?
posts.markdown:
Once upon a time, when software was shipped that wasn't perfect, it sucked. Not any more. When the App Store says that there is an update for Facebook/Dropbox/Readable because of 'bug fixes', we accept it. This was a concept that Eric Ries addressed so well in his book (an subsequental movement) [The Lean Startup.](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0307887898/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=beingre-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0307887898)

It is now okay to ship imperfect software and iron out the bugs as they are reported. This is a big plus for innovation. No longer do we need to aim for perfect, rather we need to aim for lean value: *"What are the critical functionalities that will provide the most value? - ***Let's get these right!"*** If it can happen in software, can it happen it your job and your industry? You betcha!

## Notion: knowledge is power but the accumulation of knowledge wastes time.

When we accumulate, we have the mindset of collection, the aim is to simply find and store - Wikipedia is fantastic for this.

We all know people who are accumulators. They seem very smart and spend a lot of time finding out about things...not much of which is useful for innovation, creativity, art, a cause, a movement.....just a collection of knowledge.

On the contrary, when we're aggregating we are seeking more information to help us better understand the most pressing issues around us. In aggregation, we multiply knowledge.

Do you spend most of your day accumulating or aggregating?

posts.title: What is being remarkable?
posts.markdown:
Over the last couple of weeks, I've been poking the box. I've been connecting with people simply because I want to connect with people who have an passion in entrepreneurship, blogging, unconventional lifestyles and challenging the status quo.

2012 was quite an isolated year for me. I purposely disconnected with many people to help me clarify the person who I wanted to become. Although I kept busy in the second half of the year, I was indeed disconnected from the people who I needed to be around. 

## WHAT IS BEING REMARKABLE?

Being remarkable is not an activity. It's not something that you do to get a response from people. Being remarkable is about trust, dignity, vulnerability, love, art and connection. Here is what it means to be remarkable:

* To be loved by some and hated by others, but *only*  liked by a few.
* To be beautiful to some, ugly to others, but never boring to anyone. 
* To be simple to understand for some, difficult for others, but never confusing. 

### Moments of remarkability

* When the psychiatrist tells the fiancé that his wife is sick, will take years to recover and that he will feel the highest of highs and lowest of lows. But he stays.
* The wife who sees her husband cry and simply listens to him talk.
* When the entrepreneur pitches to her tribe, listens to their feedback and ignores those on the outside who say she will fail.
* The grandparent who overcomes their fear of technology and walks into an Apple Store, simply to connect with their grandchildren.  
* When a parent tells their gay son/daughter that they love them unconditionality.
* The executive who dances on the edge of failure and fires their biggest customer because they demoralised their team.
* The student who connects a group of people who don't *fit in *with each other, gets rejected by the popular group. But follows his heart.

At each moment in life, we have a choice to do something remarkable. But doing something remarkable isn't as important as *being remarkable* .

**To be remarkable is to be truly missed when your gone.**

***

Although this blog is mostly about entrepreneurship, tribes and being remarkable in business, there will occasionally be posts such as this one. This is me and my view of the world. These posts will hopefully *center* you and put your success and failure into perspective.

Please leave a comment below if you wish to add what being remarkable means to you or other remarkable moments you'd like to share.
posts.html:
Over the last couple of weeks, I've been poking the box. I've been connecting with people simply because I want to connect with people who have an passion in entrepreneurship, blogging, unconventional lifestyles and challenging the status quo.

2012 was quite an isolated year for me. I purposely disconnected with many people to help me clarify the person who I wanted to become. Although I kept busy in the second half of the year, I was indeed disconnected from the people who I needed to be around.

WHAT IS BEING REMARKABLE?

Being remarkable is not an activity. It's not something that you do to get a response from people. Being remarkable is about trust, dignity, vulnerability, love, art and connection. Here is what it means to be remarkable:

  • To be loved by some and hated by others, but only liked by a few.
  • To be beautiful to some, ugly to others, but never boring to anyone.
  • To be simple to understand for some, difficult for others, but never confusing.

Moments of remarkability

  • When the psychiatrist tells the fiancé that his wife is sick, will take years to recover and that he will feel the highest of highs and lowest of lows. But he stays.
  • The wife who sees her husband cry and simply listens to him talk.
  • When the entrepreneur pitches to her tribe, listens to their feedback and ignores those on the outside who say she will fail.
  • The grandparent who overcomes their fear of technology and walks into an Apple Store, simply to connect with their grandchildren.
  • When a parent tells their gay son/daughter that they love them unconditionality.
  • The executive who dances on the edge of failure and fires their biggest customer because they demoralised their team.
  • The student who connects a group of people who don't *fit in *with each other, gets rejected by the popular group. But follows his heart.

At each moment in life, we have a choice to do something remarkable. But doing something remarkable isn't as important as being remarkable .

To be remarkable is to be truly missed when your gone.

Although this blog is mostly about entrepreneurship, tribes and being remarkable in business, there will occasionally be posts such as this one. This is me and my view of the world. These posts will hopefully center you and put your success and failure into perspective.

Please leave a comment below if you wish to add what being remarkable means to you or other remarkable moments you'd like to share.

posts.title: "We trust you"
posts.markdown:
The most amazing words to my ears by the coffee shop attendant when claiming a digital eCoffeeCard purchase. **"We trust you"**.

So most of us do it: we go to the same cafe 5, 10, 15 times and get a stamp (or electronic stamp in my case) to show that we're a loyal customer and claim our free coffee. Unfortunately my cellular network was down today so I could only show them that I was entitled to a free coupon but couldn't actually send through the redemption request. *Therefore, If I didn't send it through when I got back to the office, I could have rocked up tomorrow for another free coffee. (Or at least tried to). *Instead, the owner looked at me and said "We trust you".

Did I earn this trust? Not really.

Did they need to trust me? Probably not.

What was the trade off? One customer vs. one cup of coffee.

I'd buy at least 4 coffees a week from these guys, therefore 200 per year wouldn't be too far off the mark. At $3 per coffee (amazing price in Sydney CBD for a coffee with soy milk), They make $600 per year from me. Why would you save $3 to risk reducing $600 to $0.

Here's the question to reflect on: When are you being skeptical when it's so clear that trusting is a more enjoyable, remarkable and profitable experience?

posts.title: Surprise me, don't discount your art.
posts.markdown:
Firstly, I would love to thank Pat Flynn from [Smart Passive Income](http://smartpassiveincome.com/) for posting up the infographic that I made for him on Facebook. We have had hundreds of new visitors to the BeingRemarkable blog because of this post. **If you're one of them, a warm welcome to you.** ([Infographic on his Facebook Page here](https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151811135784012&set=a.195292694011.162412.173586149011&type=1&theater))

Here's my riff.

I've got a [regular coffee shop in Sydney.](http://www.dulceluna.com.au/)

Because of some work that I do, I'm entitled to a 50c discount on my coffee. I don't always receive it and I **never** ask for it. I don't want to. The coffee is great, the food is both interesting and delightful and, of course, the service is always amazing. This is what I pay my money for. It's a fair trade.

Each of the team members and the owner show up every day. They show up when I show up, just so that I feel comfortable.

Every now and then they will throw in a free Dulce Luna (see images in this post) when I buy a coffee. 

As I'm not expecting a *freebie*, it is always a welcomed surprise. In fact, I don't even use my loyalty coffee card anymore, I don't see the point. They know I am loyal and don't need to get my 11th coffee free to feel special. 

However the ultimate experience is when I bring someone here for coffee. I've received either a complimentary coffee or Dulce Luna on this occasion. When **I'm** trying to entertain/look after a friend of **mine**, and they look after **us** ...that is remarkable!

Here is the take away: your team doesn't need a loyalty policy, they need a **loyalty compass **that answers one question:

**How can we be remarkable to our loyal customers today?**
