posts.title: GET FAILURE OUT OF THE WAY. FAST.
posts.markdown:
**Fail fast, fail often.**

Once you have been successful, the world becomes scary. There is a paradox where the mass market loves to talk about an overnight success and also believe that greatness can't be repeated. Have you heard the following from a friend?

*The second movie probably isn't going to be as good as the first. (Replace first and second with any consecutive numbers)*

>*His second book can't be as good as the first.*

>*I don't know if she can turn that company around in the same way she has done in the past.*

>*I like their old music, not their new stuff.*

Being successful comes with a condition: if you want to continue making art, accept that you will be doubted and shamed for trying something new. Accept, but don't listen. People will tell you that you shouldn't try something new after you work out what works. This is the mass market who want things that are safe.

In my previous post [25 insights from Seth Godin's Startup School](http://beingremarkable.me/blog/25-insights-from-seth-godins-startup-school), I didn't mention one specific point about the diffusion of innovation. If you've been publicly successful (I believe that you can be successful with very little public knowledge), you would have firstly found your early adopters and followed by appealing to the masses. Seth asserts that some people like your work because it's new and interesting, where the mass like it because it's safe and it works.

Once you have sold your ideas to the mass market, they **will not** want you to change - it's unsafe for them.  Here is the take away:

**You ignored the mass market when you started...you didn't need them. If you want to be great again, you must ignore them again.**

* Musicians, make us feel your music.
* CEOs, lead us with courage. 
* Writers, inspire our minds.
* Marketers, tell us a story.
* Designers, show us something new.
* Everyone else, make us art that is interesting.

**You're an artist, Be Remarkable.**

posts.title: You can't have a monopoly on the moon...
posts.markdown:
...you **can** however, have a monopoly on the sunrise.

We all see the same moon. Sure, your angle might be slightly different or your $10,000 lens may make it clearer than anyone else's photo. However when someone searches Google for 'moon photos', you're likely 1 in a million (or more).

Alternatively, when you're taking a photo of a sunrise, it has context. " **Sydney Harbour Bridge Sunrise".** What makes you different is that no one will capture the Sydney Harbour Bridge like you do - your angle, the time of day, the weather on that day. Now you have a chance to be the **best in the world.** You can have a monopoly on the sunrise because your commitment to your niche will crowd out the uncommitted.

Stepping away from photography. For your business to have a monopoly, you need to be different, you need something to say, you need to make art with talking about. Don't pick a niche where you're fighting an influx of amateurs (e.g. the beach sunrise) **unless** you're willing to commit through the dip to be the best in the world.

Be remarkable.

posts.title: Are you really an entrepreneur?
posts.markdown:
In my [last post about Seth Godin's startup school](http://beingremarkable.me/blog/25-insights-from-seth-godins-startup-school), the first insight was deciding whether you are a freelancer or an entrepreneur. Upon reflecting on this post, I asked the **wrong question.** It's wrong because I'm asking you to choose your *breed*, not your role. The right question should be:

**In this project, is your role to be a freelancer or entrepreneur?**

It's wrong of me (or anyone else) to ask you to definitively choose whether you're an entrepreneur or not. There will be projects where you **must** be an entrepreneur or you will fail, and others where you **must** be a freelancer or you will fail. Choosing is a matter of deciding what story you will tell yourself when things don't go right.

Things never go right. That is, if *right* means *to plan.* You're an entrepreneur if you can handle the conflicting interests from employees, customers and investors. More importantly, you're an entrepreneur if the story you tell yourself is not about you. The story must be about something more than you. Don't listen to the world because they will tell you that it's about you. It's not. Build something that empowers you team to lead the tribe.

As an entrepreneur, your biggest challenge is **you** getting in the way **after** you have empowered your team to grow the business. Let them ship, let them fail, let them learn how to fix things themselves.

As a freelancer, you'll be tempted to *scale* your art. **Don't.** Instead, build a tribe of people who you can inspire to make their own art. Done this? You've done your job.

## You're not a freelancer if you do your job.

Doing your job is **not** following instructions. Asking for the map. Seeking permission to succeed and hiding your best work incase it fails. If you're a freelancer (design, executive, marketing...the field doesn't matter), you're being hired to make art. You're being hired to do emotional labor, and yes - you're being hired to lead.

The best consultants see change after they leave. The best designers have people talking about design, even when they're gone. The best developers inspire the entire team to code, test, and ship.

As a freelancer, you're not building a business bigger than yourself. You're leading a tribe down a path of enlightenment.

posts.title: Rights and Responsibilities: [Hint: I don't care about one]
posts.markdown:
I have the right to:

* An attorney (should I need one).
* Free speech. 
* Take my holidays.
* Get paid when I'm sick.
* Claim benefits if I'm unemployed.
* Take you to court if you offend me.
* Challenge a police officer even if I've done the wrong thing.
* Use the press to gossip about my competitors.
* Complain about the government.
* Hide.
* Fit in.
* Follow the crowd.
* Be average.

Here's the thing: **I don't care about what I'm entitled to. I care about my responsibilities.**

I have the responsibility to:

* Be bold.
* Ask questions.
* Help others.
* Add value.
* Respect beliefs.
* Influence those who want to be influenced.
* Lead those who want me to lead them.
* Be proud.
* Appreciate others.
* Listen.
* Forgive.
* Create.
* Love.
* Make art.
* Be remarkable.
